newsitem.title: ECUADOR: Anti-reform protesters holed up in Quito cathedral.
newsitem.headline: Anti-reform protesters holed up in Quito cathedral.

text.p: Hundreds of demonstrators gathered inside the Quito Cathedral in Ecuador on Wednesday to protest against economic reforms and demand the ouster of President Abdala Bucaram.
"We've been in the cathedral since 6 a.m. (1100 GMT) and we won't leave until our views are taken into account," farm workers leader Cesar Cabrera told Reuters.
Local radio said special police squads were preparing to evacuate the building.

The protest, just a few steps away from the government palace, was organised by the Coordinating Board for Social Protests which groups trade unions and women's, indigenous and Christian organisations.
Cabrera said a deputy of indian descent, Manuel Lluco, and the former president of the CONAIE indigenous peoples federation, Jose Maria Cabascagno, were among the protesters.
CONAIE is the most powerful indigenous group in Ecuador, whose population is 47 percent of indian origin.
Cabrera said the Board sought the repeal of huge public tariff hikes and plans to launch a currency convertibility plan pegging the sucre, the Ecuadoran currency, to the dollar.

It also wants a plebiscite on the government's privatisation plans and is demanding the ouster of President Abdala Bucaram and the impeachments of Energy Minister Alfredo Adum and State Prosecutor Leonidas Plaza.
"The decision of the Board is to stay at this site indefinitely. We call on all believers and Christians to come to the cathedral and back this occupation," Cabrera said.
Students have led violent protests in recent weeks and the unions called a general strike for Feb. 5 in reaction to economic cutbacks by the six-month-old Bucaram administration.
The measures have caused electricity and gas rates to soar more than 200 percent and public transport fares to rise 60 percent. Telephone rates were also expected to shoot up.
